body:
Hi @HugangRen, it looks like the API request to log metrics in this case simply timed out (i.e. there may have been a loss of network connectivity on your training machine etc)

You can reduce the number of API requests made by using [`mlflow.log_metrics`](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.html#mlflow.log_metrics), or the lower-level [`MlflowClient.log_batch`](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.tracking.html#mlflow.tracking.MlflowClient.log_batch) method, which should speed up metric-logging & thereby reduce the odds of hitting connectivity / server-load-related issues. If you don't necessarily need all metrics logged, you can also try-catch the logging calls to ensure they don't fail your training program.

Given that you seem to be using Keras, I'd also encourage you to try the `mlflow.keras.autolog()` API (or `mlflow.tensorflow.autolog()` if using tf.keras), [see docs](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#tensorflow-and-keras-experimental), which perform logging asynchronously during training & do not throw on logging failures

Hi @smurching , thank you for your answer. The connection seems fine. I was not sure whether it is because I am calling too many times of mlflow.log_metrics API and the server was not able to respond in time to all of them and in the middle time out happened.

When I changed it to this:

    for epoch in range(0, epochs):
        try:
            mlflow.log_metric(key="Accuracy", value=acc[epoch], step=epoch)
            mlflow.log_metric(key="Validation Accuracy", value=val_acc[epoch], step=epoch)
           mlflow.log_metric(key="Loss", value=loss[epoch], step=epoch)
            mlflow.log_metric(key="Validation Loss", value=val_loss[epoch], step=epoch)
       except TimeoutError:
           time.sleep(5)
           mlflow.log_metric(key="Accuracy", value=acc[epoch], step=epoch)
           mlflow.log_metric(key="Validation Accuracy", value=val_acc[epoch], step=epoch)
           mlflow.log_metric(key="Loss", value=loss[epoch], step=epoch)
           mlflow.log_metric(key="Validation Loss", value=val_loss[epoch], step=epoch)

It works but logging did take very long time.

I also tried mlflow.tensorflow.autolog() as you suggested, it logged one single value of the metrics (e.g., Accuracy, Validation Accuracy, Loss, Validation Loss). I want to log the value for each epoch so that I can view it in a similar way as in TensorBoard to see how the metrics change with epoch. Is it possible with mlflow.tensorflow.autolog() ? Or did I not set something correctly?

Also, if I use mlflow.tensorflow.autolog(), the model is always logged. The model file size is a little bit large. To save the storage space, I do not want to log all models unless they are promising.  So finer control is needed. Autolog is nice and very easy to use but has its limitation too.

> Hi @HugangRen, it looks like the API request to log metrics in this case simply timed out (i.e. there may have been a loss of network connectivity on your training machine etc)
> 
> You can reduce the number of API requests made by using [`mlflow.log_metrics`](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.html#mlflow.log_metrics), or the lower-level [`MlflowClient.log_batch`](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.tracking.html#mlflow.tracking.MlflowClient.log_batch) method, which should speed up metric-logging & thereby reduce the odds of hitting connectivity / server-load-related issues. If you don't necessarily need all metrics logged, you can also try-catch the logging calls to ensure they don't fail your training program.
> 
> Given that you seem to be using Keras, I'd also encourage you to try the `mlflow.keras.autolog()` API (or `mlflow.tensorflow.autolog()` if using tf.keras), [see docs](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#tensorflow-and-keras-experimental), which perform logging asynchronously during training & do not throw on logging failures

@HugangR Can you provide more details about your MLflow Server setup to help us reproduce this issue? Are you running the MLflow Server on a remote cloud instance? Behind a proxy? etc?

@HugangR You raise a great point about `mlflow.tensorflow.autolog()`'s verbosity. Can you file a follow-up feature request to an add an option to reduce the amount of information logged during autologging? I.e. a flag to specify that artifacts should not be logged.

> @HugangR Can you provide more details about your MLflow Server setup to help us reproduce this issue? Are you running the MLflow Server on a remote cloud instance? Behind a proxy? etc?
> 
> @HugangR You raise a great point about `mlflow.tensorflow.autolog()`'s verbosity. Can you file a follow-up feature request to an add an option to reduce the amount of information logged during autologging? I.e. a flag to specify that artifacts should not be logged.

@dbczumar , the MLflow server is running on a VM in Azure cloud. I am accessing the server from my local computer through the http link. When I access it from my company network, I believe it is behind a proxy, as most companies have proxy.

That will be helpful. Especially if you can control model files are not logged every single time when a training job starts. The log files and metrics generally do not take up that much storage space.

@HugangR Can you provide some more details? Are you using `tf.keras`/`keras` or raw `tensorflow`? The behavior of `mlflow.tensorflow.autolog` & `mlflow.keras.autolog` is that the model should only be logged at the end of the training (which includes all the metrics that you have logged during the training). Let us know if that is not the case and we would love to follow up on that. We would also suggest file a feature request for disabling artifact logging from the autolog API as suggested by @dbczumar

> @HugangR Can you provide some more details? Are you using `tf.keras`/`keras` or raw `tensorflow`? The behavior of `mlflow.tensorflow.autolog` & `mlflow.keras.autolog` is that the model should only be logged at the end of the training (which includes all the metrics that you have logged during the training). Let us know if that is not the case and we would love to follow up on that. We would also suggest file a feature request for disabling artifact logging from the autolog API as suggested by @dbczumar

I am using tf.keras. autolog to log everything every time works. Finer control is desired.
